Rural Electrification.Description: Rural electrification often relies on renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, or hydro power to provide sustainable electricity to remote areas.

Rural electrification projects often employ microgrids, which are localized power grids that can operate independently or in conjunction with the main grid, to efficiently distribute electricity in rural areas.

Rural electrification initiatives require energy storage solutions such as batteries or pumped hydro storage to store excess electricity generated during peak production periods for use during low production periods or during power outages.

Smart grids, which enable two-way communication between the electricity provider and consumers, can enhance the efficiency and reliability of rural electrification projects by optimizing electricity distribution and enabling demand response.
